I know the past few months have been hard for many. But now is not the time to ease up. It's the time to stay vigilant, stay committed, and stay home -- and continue to save lives. The faster we stop the spread of COVID-19, the quicker our city and economy can begin to recover.

The recovery planning team will examine what a "new normal" must be to maintain control over the virus and protect our health. These decisions will impact services like libraries and parks, as well as how we can safely ride the TTC, use our streets, and help the most vulnerable.

A new recovery team will guide Toronto’s work, while Dr. de Villa and Chief Pegg continue to focus on COVID-19 mitigation. This team will be lead by public health expert Dr. David Mowat and Saad Rafi, who managed the 2015 Pan Am Games, and will determine when services may resume.

The recovery and rebuild phase means considering which activities and operations may slowly resume, and which ones we need to continue to delay -- and looking at this challenge, first and foremost, through a public health lens.

We must begin, though, to plan for how we can start to take cautious steps towards recovery. Recovery will not happen overnight. Most of our population still has no immunity to the virus, and a full return to normal life will not be possible until there is a vaccine for COVID-19.

Even though we may be nearing the peak of infection rates within the general population, we can’t take our foot off the gas now. We must continue to physically distance and stay home. Abandoning the rules now would waste all the hard work and sacrifice of the past five weeks.

Our data also shows a second pandemic: the one in congregate living sites like long term care and retirement homes, shelters and group homes, where cases tragically continue to rise. We must step up our efforts to protect staff and residents, many of whom are our most vulnerable.

For the past three months, we've worked around the clock to contain and mitigate the spread of COVID-19, led by the best advice from our public health experts.  Our data shows that what we’ve been doing is working -- Toronto is flattening the curve of community transmission.

This pandemic has forever changed us. It’s exposed the cracks in our health care system, our public services, how we treat our most vulnerable. It’s also shown our compassion, courage, and resiliency. Let’s use these lessons as we look ahead to our next big challenge: Recovery.
